Hi Dominik,

thanks for the pull request.

Groovy still supports Java 6, so it can not be merged as it is: http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=26394&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk6Build

The groovy-nio subproject supports java 7. I do not know if it makes sense to move the methods to `org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.NioGroovyMethods`, what do you think?
Thanks!

This also contains minor refactorings: not having a special-purpose default closure, and passing around the url "jrt:/" instead of duplicating it.

Related to this:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/commit/0e384ec3
and this:
http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/jigsaw-dev/2014-November/004044.html

With this PR, I guess the test would break when running against earlier alphas of Java9 (I was using 1.9.0-ea-b76, ot sure which one was used on buildfarm). Not sure if anyone cares. If so, it might be possible to hack something that tries to act differntly on different early Java9 versions.

Thanks you very much. :)

No need to worry about earlier alphas imho.

The groovy buildserver builds jdk9 from source once a week.
Good to merge I guess?
Nice :), good to merge I guess.
Main reason I hadn't was I was trying to decide whether to wait for [GROOVY-7557](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7557) to simplify things.

I did not follow the discussion on GROOVY-7557, but if it is implemented I think it will only be for 2.5/3.0. Therefore documenting the current behavior is a good idea imho. Of course it's up to you to decide when to merged the pull request. :)

Yea, you're probably right.  Some of what I proposed are breaking changes.  Just such a stupidly big table...  The way 7557 could make it smaller is if the behavior were consistent across the primitive and wrapper types, the table could be 1/2 the width with a note below it saying something like "the primitives have the same behavior as the wrapper types in the table".  But as it is today, sometimes you can convert using the wrapper, sometimes you can't.

Hi Esteban,

thanks for the pull request. :)

You talking about getXZYPath() has me wondering if your fix will work with Java 6 (because Groovy still supports that)?

Thanks,
Pascal

Since Pascal asked for a review, I would say: It would be nice to have regression tests for: 
- invoking closeWithWarning() with closeable closes closeable
- invoking closeWithWarning() with null does not fail
- invoking closeWithWarning() with closeable that throws Exception on close() does not throw Exception
- invoking withAutoCloseable() closes even when action throws exception
- invoking withAutoCloseable() closes even when action throws exception e1, and e1 is thrown even when close() throws another exception e2.

The code could have a brief comment explaining the strategy of wrapping the call to close in case the call to self action fails, so that the first Exception is not swallowed by the second.

Also withAutoCloseable is vulnerable to invoking with null, will throw NPE. That might be okay, I just thought I mention it.
Good question let me check the jdk 6 java docs I suppose team city will also tell us if the test breaks
merged, thanks!

After checking the documentation, I can confirm this patch will work in the JDK6.
The JDK6 has basically the same methods using File as a return type. These methods will be excluded from the serialization. However their counterpart methods return String(as opposed to Path in JDK7+ )
, which meas they will get properly serialized in json. Eg

File getParentFile() ----> skipped
(String|Path) getParent() ----> serialized to [parent='/some/path/']

Thus no loss of information/ no recursive references to File object.
Made a mistake in previous comment, the JDK7 does not use Path as the return type of the methods, it uses String.

One comment I would make regarding this, if we start adding `isAssignableFrom` checks for every possible type then the performance is going to start to suffer. It may be that there needs to be an extensible codec mechanism added instead.
Rebased, added commits for GROOVY-7585, some refactorings, and tests

Merged into master and 2.4.x, thanks!

Interesting.

On a slightly different topic: how difficult would it be to support unbound ranges also, like in `https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/wiki/RangesExplained`.

I don't know about the syntax, I guess `_..10` or `(..10)` or `<..10`.

Or ranges with non-integer step size, i.e. `0.1, 0.11, 0.11 ... 0.2` as `0.1..0.01..0.2` or at least to support decimals in the ObjectRange's step setter :/

Let me know if you consider this off topic and will post it in the issues instead.

non-integer ranges are already kind-of supported in Groovy. Ranges are defined by the "next()" method on the instances, which for 0.1..10 yields [0.1, 0.2, 0.3 ...]
Ranges can either be inspired by for-loops (having an increment step), or by mathematic intervals. Given Guava has ranges as you point out, I am not sure if Groovy should go out of its way to implement the same thing. 

Changing the grammar so that the parse can parse a larger variety of ranges should not be that difficult technically, but you may face resistance from language designers. Changing the code for the ranges an be a bit challenging, in particular since you must not break existing usages.

I am not sure if you are volunteering to work on this, or asking for this to be done. In any case I'd say the mailing lists are a good start to try to get support: http://www.groovy-lang.org/mailing-lists.html

> `0.1..10` yields `[0.1, 0.2, 0.3 ...]`

actually it yields `[0.1, 1.1, ..., 9.1]`, because it has a step size of `1`, so e.g. `(0.1..0.5).collect()` will yield `[0.1]`

> I am not sure if you are volunteering to work on this, or asking for this to be done.

Would gladly contribute, will ask the mailing list for opinions, thanks :)
sorry for wrong info about floats.
Should play well with https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/pull/109
Really if we're going to do this (and I agree we should), we might as well go all the way and have fields for all the other strings too.
@keeganwitt I agree. I'm not actually sure of the full list, but if one exists then I can update the PR to do that instead.

your change currently has two obvious problems. (1) returning Collections.emptyList() is only ok, if you say, that the result cannot be modified. The old implementation did not have this. You even had to change a test for this. (2) You changed step(int) to step(Number). This is not binary compatible. Java programs using Range directly will have to recompile. They will do so just fine, since Java will do the boxing, but an old library will not work with these new Ranges

Hello @blackdrag,

1) I will document it, if you think it's necessary, though I think it was already specified that it returned an empty list - and not that it returned a new list.
Also, why would people modify a list, returned by an empty range?

2) You're right, I will add a delegate method (deprecating it would be weird, as `int` is probably the most common usage).
An empty list can still be a list that gets elements added.  One more thing... can you show me the benchmark code you did for ObjectRange as well?

Yes, I changed the description to `immutable empty list`.

The `ObjectRange` is described in the above message in the comment: `// changed to i = 0G when testing ObjectRange`

If we did "indy", one option we should add for sure is "int", since most callers will want to disable that if they're enabling indy.  We also should replace all occurrences with the static reference I think.  Which would include
- GroovyMain
- ClassNodeResolver
- FileSystemCompiler
- Groovy (in groovy-ant module)

Others we might consider are
- all (another option for optimizationOptions)
- stubDir
- keepStubs
- namedValues
- flags

For options that are kept in maps, maybe an enum as the key instead of a bunch of static strings would be better anyway.  Not sure how @melix would feel about that idea.
I'm thinking ones we probably _wouldn't_ do would be all the system properties (e.g. "groovy.source.encoding", "groovy.target.bytecode", etc).  I don't think those would be programmatically set.
Agreed. It's uncommon to expose system properties.

CI trigger for pull request would be very helpful (we had this before the move to apache), but I was told it's not possible with teamcity and the read-only apache github mirror.

Thanks, the problem was, that in case of enums, at the boundaries, the `previous` and `next` methods have wrapped to the other extreme.
I.e. `next` for the last element returned the first one (I didn't know this was legal behavior).
Added a separate test case for this and for `null` values also.

`Tests passed: 9696, ignored: 22`
http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=27169&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk7Build

+1 this has become a real problem for us too because we use gh-pages to publish our docs so each time we publish it creates huge commits because every javadoc has changed

It also prevents us from publishing snapshots because the change sets are too big.

The patch only removes the timestamps and preserves the version of Groovy used (javadoc's `-notimestamp` option removes both). Removing the version might be desirable too in your case, otherwise you'll still get large change sets when upgrading to a new version of Groovy.
upgrading Groovy is less frequent, so I'm not as concerned about that

It wouldn't be that hard to make both configurable but I'll have a bit of a closer look at what the JavaDoc code does before commenting further here if needed. It seems like this is a fairly straight-forward change even if some minor tweaking might be desirable.

Here is the link to the relevant code in javadoc:

http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8u/jdk8u/langtools/file/f166261986cc/src/share/classes/com/sun/tools/doclets/formats/html/markup/HtmlDocWriter.java#l329
JavaDoc doesn't have version as an option, so I think a separate flag would make sense for that. I am happy to merge your request and add the extra flag in the next day or two hopefully.
I did a minor tweak to ensure that the new behavior was backwards compatible by default but otherwise merged your proposal. I also then added a `noversionstamp` flag too. Thanks!
Thank you!

Actually the issue is not completely fixed, I didn't notice the templates also include the date with a `<meta>` tag:

```
<meta name="date" content="${new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd')}">
```

This line should be removed when `-notimestamp` is specified.
Amended. Nice pick up.
Thank you for the quick fix
